editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Let us make use of this stolen privacy,
And not loose time in protestation, mistress,
For 'twere in me a kind of breach of faith,
To say again I love you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Sweet speak softly
For though the venture of your love to me,
Meets with a willing, and a full return:
Should it arrive unto my father's knowledge;
These were our last discourse.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: How shall he know it?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: His watching cares are such, for my advancement,
That everywhere his eye is fixed upon me:
This night that does afford us some small freedom,
At the request and much entreaty of,
The mistress of the house, was hardly given me:
For I am never suffered to stir out,
But he hath spies upon me, yet I know not
You have so won upon me, that could I think
You would love faithfully (Though to entertain
Another thought of you, would be my death)
I should adventure on his utmost anger.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why, do you think I can be false?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: No faith,
You have an honest face, but if you should —

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Let all the stored vengeance of heaven's justice —

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: No more, I do believe you, the dance ended,
Which this free woman's guests have vowed to have
Ere they depart, I will make home, and store me
With all the jewels, chains, and gold are trusted
Unto my custody, and at the next corner,
To my father's house, before one at the farthest,
Be ready to receive me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I desire
No bond beyond your promise, let's go in,
To talk thus much before the door, may breed,
Suspicion. Enter Mercury and Antonio talking.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Here are company too.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Away,
Those powers that prosper true and honest loves
Will bless our undertakeings.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: 'Tis my wish sir. Exit Rich and Viol.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nay, sir, excuse me, I have drawn you to,
Too much expense already in my travel:
And you have been too forward in your love;
To make my wants your own, allow me manners
Which you must grant I want, should I increase,
The bond in which your courtesies have tide me:
Be still consuming you, give me leave
To take mine own ways now; and I shall often
With willingness come to visit you, and then thank you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By this hand I could be angry, what do you think me?
Must we that have so long time, been as one
Seen cities, countries, kingdoms, and their wonders
Been bedfellows, and in our various journey
Mixed all our observations, part (As if
We were 2. Carriers at 2. several ways,
And as the fore-horse guides, cry God be with you)
Without or compliment, or ceremony?
In travellers that know transalpine garbs,
Though our designs are ne'er so serious, friend,
It were a capital crime; it must not be,
Nay what is more, you shall not, you ere long
Shall see my house, and find what I call mine
Is wholly at your service.

sp.speaker: Mer,
sp.l: 'Tis this tires me,
Sir I were easily wooed if nothing else
But my will lay in the choice, but 'tis not so
My friends and kindred that have part of me,
And such on whom my chiefest hopes depend,
Justly expect the tender of my love
After my travel, than mine own honesty
Tells me 'tis poor, having indifferent means
To keep me in my quality and rank,
At my return to tire another's bounty,
And let mine own grow lusty, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will not, cannot, to conclude I dare not:
Can any thing conferred upon my friend
Be burdensome to me? for this excuse
Had I no reason else you should not leave me,
By a traveller's faith you should not, I have said,
And than you know my humour, there's no contending.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Is there no way to scape this inundation?
I shall be drowned with folly if I go:
And after 9. days men may take me up,
With my gall broken.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you yet resolved?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Wood you would spare me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By this light I cannot
By all, that may be sworn by.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Patience help me,
And heaven grant his folly be not catching:
If it be, the towns undone, I now would give
A reasonable sum of gold to any sheriff,
That would but lay an execution on me,
And free me from his company; while he was abroad,
His want of wit and language kept him dumb:
But Balaam's ass will speak now without spurring.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speak, have I won you? —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are not to be resisted.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Be ready I entreat you the dance done,
Besides a liberal reward I have,
A bottle of sherry in my power shall beget
New crotchets in your heads.

sp.speaker: Musician
sp.l: Tush fear not us, we'll do our parts.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Go in,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know this fellow.
Belong you to the house?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I serve the mistress.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pretty, and short, pray you sir then inform her,
Two gentlemen are covetous to be honoured,
With her fair presence.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: She shall know so much,
This is a merry night with us, and forbid not
Welcome to any that looks like a man:
I'll guide you the way.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay follow, I have a trick in't. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Uberto, Silvio, Richardo, Maria, Pedro.

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.l: Come where's this mask? fairest for our cheer,
Our thanks and service, may you long survive,
To joy in many of these nights.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.l: We must have music too, or else you give us,
But half a welcome.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray you sir excuse me.

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.l: By no means lady.

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.l: We'll crown your liberal feast,
With some delightful strain fitting your love:
And this good company.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Since you enforce it,
I will not plead the excuse of want of skill
Or be, or nice, or curious, every year,
I celebrate my marriage night; and will
Till I see my absent husband.

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.l: 'Tis fit freedom.

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.l: Richardo thou art dull —

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I shall be lighter,
When I have had a heat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now sir, the news?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Mistress there are 2. Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Complementing who should first enter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Heaven knows, but for their strangeness, have you never seen a cat wash her face?

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Just such a stir they keep if you make but haste,
You may see 'em yet before they enter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Let 'em be what they will, we'll give them fair
Entertain, and gentle welcome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Then let it be your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let's stand aside and you shall see us have
Fine sport anon.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A fair society, do you know these gentle women?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The second is a neighbour's daughter, her name is Viola.
There is my kinsman's wife, Portia her name, and a
Friend too.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Let her — what's she that leads the dance?

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: A gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I see that.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: A gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Udsfoote, good sir what's she that leads the dance?

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: My mistress.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What else?

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: My mistress, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Your mistress? A pox on you, what a fry of fools are here? I see 'tis treason to understand in this house; if nature were not better to them, than they can be to themselves, they would scant hit their mouths; my mistress? Is there any one with so much wit in is head, that can tell me at the first sight, what gentlewoman that is that leads the dance?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis my wife.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How dost thou like her?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Well, a pretty gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prithee be quiet.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I would I could
Let never any hereafter that's a man,
That has affections in him and free passions,
Receive the least tie from such a fool as this is,
That holds so sweet a wife, 'tis lamentable to consider truly
What right he robs himself of, and what wrong
He doth the youth of such a gentlewoman?
That knows her beauty is no longer hers,
Than men will please to make it so, and use it
Neither of which lies freely in a husband,
Oh what have I done, what have I done, coxcomb?
If I had never seen, or never tasted
The goodness of this kix, I had been a made man,
But now to make a cuckold is a sin
Against all forgiveness, worse than a murder;
I have a wolf by the ears, and am bitten both ways.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now friend, what are you thinking of?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nothing concerning you, I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pardon me, I'll have no going sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Then good sir give me leave to go to bed,
I am very weary and ill tempered.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You shall presently, the dance is done.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: Mistress, these are the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My husband will come home, dear sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She's fair still, oh that I were a knave or durst be one,
For thy sake coxcomb; he that invented honesty, undid me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I had you had not known me, you're merry 'tis well thought,
And how is't with these worthy gent?

sp.speaker: Vb. and Sil.
sp.l: We are glad to see you here again

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O gent, what ha'you lost? but get you into travels,
There you may learn, I cannot say what hidden virtues.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Hidden from you I am sure,
My blood boils like a furnace,
She's a fair one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pray entertain this gent. with all the courtesy,
Fitting my most especial friend.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What this poor house may yield,
To make you welcome dear sir command
Without more compliment.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I thank you:
She's wise and speaks well too, o what a blessing
Is gone by me near to be recovered?
sp.p: Well, 'twas an old shame the devil laid up for me, and now has hit me home; if there be any ways to be dishonest and save myself yet, — no it must not be, why should I be a fool to — yet those eyes would tempt another Adam, how they call to me, and tell me — sfoot they shall not tell me any thing, sir will you walk in.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How is't signior?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Crazy a little.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What ail you sir?
What's in my power pray make use of, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis that must do me good, she does not mock me sure,
An't please you nothing, my disease is only weariness.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: Come gent. we'll not keep you from your beds too long.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I ha' some business, and 'tis late, and you far from your lodging.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Well. Exit. Manent, Ant. Mar. and Mer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come my dear Mercury, I'll bring you to your chamber, and then I am for you, Maria, thou art a new wife to me now, and thou shalt find it, ere I sleep.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And I, an old ass to myself, mine own rod whips me, — good sir no more of this, 'tis tedious, you
are the best guide in your own house — go sir —
sp.l: This fool, and his fair wife have made me frantic
From two such physics for the soul, deliver me.

div.stage: Enter Richardo, Uberti, Pedro, and Silvio.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: Well, you must have this wench then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I hope so, I am much o'th bow hand else.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Wood I were hanged, 'tis a good loving little fool that dares venture herself upon a coast she never knew yet, but these women, when they are once thirteen, god speed the plough.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Faith they'll venture further, so their lading then a merchant, and through as many storms, but they'll be fraughted, they are made like carrecks only strength and storage.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Come, come, you talk, you talk.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: We do so, but tell me Richardo, wilt thou marry her?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Marry her? why what should I do with her?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Pox, I thought we should have had all shares in her like lawful prize.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: No by my faith sir, you shall pardon me, I launched her at my own charge without partners, and so I'll keep her.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: What's the hour?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Twelve.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: What shall we do the while? 'tis yet scarce eleven.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: There's no standing here, is not this the place?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And to go back unto her father's house, may breed suspicion lets slip into a tavern, for an hour, 'tis very cold.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: Content, there is one hard by, a quart of burned sack will recover us, I am as cold as Christmas, this stealing flesh in the frosty weather, may be sure ith' eating, but sure the woodmen have no great catch on't; shall's go?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Thou art the strangest lover of a tavern, what shall we do there now? lose the hour and ourselves too?

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: Lose a pudding; what dost thou talk of the hour; will one quart muzzle us? have we not ears to hear, and tongues to ask the drawers, but we must stand here like bawds to watch the minutes?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Prithee content thyself, we shall scout here, as though we went a haying, and have some mangey prentice, that cannot sleep for scratching, over ear us, come will you go sirs? when your love fury is a little frozen, you'll come to us.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Will you drink but one quart then?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: No more i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why then, have with you, but let's be very watchful

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: As watchful as the bellman, come I'll lead, because I hate good manners, they are too tedious. Exeunt.
sp.stage: Enter Viola with a key and a little casket.
sp.l: The night is terrible and I enclosed
With that my virtue and myself hate most,
Darkness; yet must I fear that which I wish,
Some company, and every step I take
Sounds louder in my fearful ears tonight
Then ever did, the shrill and sacred bell
That rang me to my prayers; the house will rise
When I unlock the door, were it by day
I am bold enough, but then a thousand eyes
Warn me from going, might not God have made
A time for envious prying folk to sleep
Whilst lovers met, and yet the sun have shone?
Yet I was bold enough, to steal this key
Out of my father's chamber, and dare yet
Venture upon mine enemy, this night,
Armed only with my love, to meet my friend.
Alas how valiant, and how 'fraid at once
Love makes a virgin? I will throw this key
Back through a window, I had wealth enough
In jewels with me, if I hold his love
I steal 'em for; farewell my place of birth,
I never make account to look on thee again;
And if there be as I have heard men say,
These household gods, I do beseech them look
To this my charge, bless it from thieves and fire,
And keep till happily my love I win
Me from thy door, and hold my father in. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Richardo, Pedro, Uberti, Silvio, and drawer with a candle.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: No more for God sake, how is the night boy?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Faith sir 'tis very late.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: Faith sir you lie, is this your jack i'th clockhouse? will you strike sir? gi's some more sack, you varlet.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Nay, if you love me, good Uberti go,
I am monstrous hot with wine.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: Quench it again with love, gent. I will-drinke one health more, and then if my legs say me not shamefully nay, I will go with you, give me a singular quart.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Of what wine sir?

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.p: Of sack, you that speak confusion at the bar, of sack I say, and every one his quart, what a devil let's be merry.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: You shall sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: We will sir, and a dried tongue.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And an olive, boy, and a whole bunch of fiddlers, my head swims plaguely, uds precious I shall be claud.

div.stage: Enter drawer with four quarts of wine.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Pray go, I can drink no more, think on your promise, 'tis midnight gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: O that it were dumb midnight now, not a word more, every man on's knees, and betake himself to his saint, here's to your wench, seignor, all this, and then away.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I cannot drink it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: 'Tis a toy, a toy, away wilt.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.p: Now dare I speak any thing, to anybody living, come where's the fault? off with it.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I have broke my wind, call you this sack? — I wonder who made it? he was a sure workman, for 'tis plaguy strong work, is it gone round?

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: 'Tis at the last out of my way, good boy, is the moon up yet?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: Where is she boy?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: There sir.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: We shall have rain and thunder, boy.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: When sir?

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: I cannot tell, but sure we shall, boy.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: The gent. is wine wise.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: Drawer?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: Can you procure?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: A whore or two or three as need shall serve, boy?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ay, a good whore were worth money, boy.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: I protest sir we are all together unprovided.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: The more's the pity, boy, can you not 'vise us where my child?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Neither, in troth sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why where were you brought up boy? no juggling of a whore? no aim my boy?

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.p: It cannot sink in my head now, that thou shouldst marry, why shouldst thou marry, tell me?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I marry? I'll be hanged first: some more wine boy.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Is she not a whore translated? And she be, let's repair to her.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I cannot tell, she may be an offender; but signior Silvio I shall scratch your head, indeed I shall.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Judge me I do most jest with thee, what an she were inverted with her heels upward, like a traitor's coat? what care I.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: Ay, hang her, shall we fall out for her?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I am a little angry, but these wenches, did you not talk of wenches?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Boy lend me your candle.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: To set fire to your rotten feeling, you'll keep no
Whores, rogue, no good members;

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Whores sir?

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.p: Ay, whores, sir, do you think we come to lie with your hogsheads?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I must beat the watch, I have longed for't any time this three weeks.

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.p: We'll beat the town too, and thou wilt, we are proof boy; shall we kill anybody ?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: No but we'll hurt 'em dangerously.

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.p: Silu. Now must I kill one, I cannot avoid it, boy easily afore there with your candle; where's your mistress?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: A bed, sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: With my master.

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.p: You lie boy, she's better brought up then to lie with her husband, has he not cast his head yet? next year he will be a velvet-headed cuckold.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: You are a merry gentleman, there sir, take holdExeunt.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: This is the place I have out told the clock,
For haste, he is not here. Richardo? no;
Now every power that loves and is beloved:
Keep me from shame tonight , for all you know
Each thought of mine is innocent, and pure,
As flesh and blood can hold: I cannot back;
I threw the key within, and ere I raise
My father up, to see his daughter's shame,
I'll set me down, and tell the Northern wind,
That it is gentler than the curling West;
If it will blow me dead, but he will come;
I'faith 'tis cold; if he deceive me thus,
A woman will not easily trust a man. Hark what's that?

sp.speaker: Sil within.
sp.p: Thou'rt over long at thy pot, tom, tom, thou art over long at the pot Tom.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Bless me! who's that?

sp.speaker: Pedro within.
sp.l: Who!

sp.speaker: Uber. within.
sp.l: There boys.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Darkness be thou my cover, I must fly,
To thee I haste for help —

div.stage: Enter Richardo, Pedro, Uberto, drawer with a torch.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: They have a light,
Wind if thou lovest a virgin blow it out,
And I will never shut a window more,
To keep thee from me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Boy?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why boy?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: What say you sir?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why boy? art thou drunk boy?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: What would you sir?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why very good, where are we?

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.l: Ay, that's the point.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Why sir, you will be at your lodging presently.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I'll go to no lodging boy.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Whether will you go then sir?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I'll go no farther.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: For god's sake sir, do not stay here all night.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: No more I will not boy, lay me down, and roll me to a whore.

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.l: And me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There spoke an —

sp.speaker: Silvio.
sp.l: Then set your foot to my foot, and up tails all.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: That is Richardo, what a noise they make?
'Tis ill don on 'em: here sirs, Richardo?

sp.speaker: Rich ..
sp.l: What's that boy?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: 'Tis a wench sir, pray gent. come away.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O my dear love! how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: My sweet heart? even as thou seest.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Where's thy wench?

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.l: Where's this bed worm?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Speak softly for the love of heaven.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Mistress get you gone, and do not entice the gent. Now you see they're drunk, or I'll call the watch, and lay you fast enough.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Alas what are you? or what do you mean?
Sweet love where's the place?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Marry sweet love, e'en here, lie down I'll feeze you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Good god! what mean you?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I'll have the wench.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: If you can get her.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: No I'll lie with the wench tonight , and she shall be yours tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Let go the wench.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Let you go the wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O gent. as you had mothers!

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: They had no mothers, they are the sons of bitches

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Let that be maintained.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Marry then.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O bless me heaven!

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: How many is there on's?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: About five.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.p: Why then let's fight three to three. Draw and fall down.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: The watch? the watch? the watch? where are you? Exit.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Where are these cowards?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There's the whore.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I never saw a drunken man before,
But these I think are so.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I missed you narrowly there.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My state is such, I know not how to think,
A prayer fit for me, only I could move,
That never maiden more might be in love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.l: Where are they, boy?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Make no such haste sir, they are no runners.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: I am hurt, but that's all one, I shall light upon some of ye,
Pedro thou art a tall gent. let me kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.l: My friend.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: Your friend? you lie.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Stand further off, the watch, you are full of fleas.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Gent either be quiet, or we must make you quiet.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay good Mr. Constable, be not so rigorous.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: Mr. Constable lend me thy hand of justice.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: That I will sir.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.p: Fie Mr. constable what golls you have? is justice so blind she cannot see to wash your hands? I cry you mercy sir; your gloves are one.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Now you are up sir, will you go to bed?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I'll truckle here boy, give me another pillow.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Will you stand up and let me lay it on then?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: There hold him two of ye, now they are up be going Mr. constable

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: And this way, and that way, tom.

sp.speaker: Uber.
sp.l: And here away and there away Tom.

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.l: This is the right way the others the wrong.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Th' others the wrong.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thou art over long at the pot Tom, tom.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Lead valiantly sweet constable, whoop! ha boys!

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: This wine hunts in their heads.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Give me the bill, for I'll be the sergeant.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Look to him sirs.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Keep your ranks you rascals, keep your ranks.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: I cannot sleep for thinking of this ass's wife, I'll be gone presently, there's no staying here, with this devil about me? ho, this is the house of sleep, ho? again there's foot the darkness, and this love together, will make me lunatic; ho?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Who calls there?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Pray take the pains to rise and light a candle.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Presently,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Was ever man but I in such a stocks? well this shall be a warning to me, and a fair one too, how I betray myself to such a dunce, by way of benefit.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Did you call?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, pray do me the kindness sir, to let me out and not to inquire why, for I must needs be gone.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Not tonight , I hope sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good sir tonight , I would not have troubled you else, pray let it be so.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Alas sir, my master will be offended.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That I have business? no I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Good sir take your rest.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Pray my good friend let me appoint my own rest.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Then show me the way out, I'll consider you.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Good lord, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If I had not an excellent tempered patience, now should I break this fellow's head, and make him understand 'twere necessary; the only plague of this house is the unhandsome love of servants, that near do their duty in the right place, but when they muster before dinner, and sweep the table with a wooden dagger, and then they are troublesome too, to all men's shoulders, the woodcocks fleshed again, now I shall have a new stir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why how now friend? what do you up so late? are you well? do you want any thing? pray speak.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Only the cause I rise for.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What knaves are these? what do you want? why sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nothing i'the world, but the keys to let me out of doors; I must be gone, be not against it, for you cannot stay me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Begun at this time? that were a merry jest.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If there be any mirth in't, make you use on't, but I must go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why for love's sake?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Twill benefit your understanding nothing to know the cause, pray go to bed, I'll trouble your man only.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay sir you have raised more, that has reason to curse you, and you knew all, my wife's up, and coming down too.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Alas it will be a trouble, pray go up to her and let me disturb no more, 'tis unmannerly.

div.stage: Enter wife as out of her bed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: She's here already; sweet heart: how say you by this gentleman? he would away at midnight.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: That I am sure he will not.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Indeed I must.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Good sir let not your homely entertainment press you to leave your bed at midnight; if you want, what my house or your town may afford you, make it your own fault if you call not for it pray go to bed again; let me compel you, I am sure you have no power to deny a woman; the air is piercing, and to a body beaten with long travel, 'twill prove an ill physician.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If she speak longer I shall be a knave, as rank as ever sweat for't; sir if you will send your wife up presently, I will either stay with you, d'ye mark, me or deliver you, so just a cause, that you yourself, shall thrust me out of doors, both suddenly and willingly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I would fain hear that faith, pray thee go up sweet heart, I have half persuaded him, besides, he hath some private business with me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good night sir, and what content you would have, I wish with you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Could any man that had a back ask more? O me! O me!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now deal directly with me: why should you go?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If you be wise do not inquire the cause, 'twill trouble you:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why? prithee why?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Faith I would not have you know it, let me go, 'twill be far better for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who's that, that knocks there? is't not at the street door?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who's there, cannot you speak?

sp.speaker: Within Vio.
sp.l: A poor distressed maid, for god's sake let me in.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Let her in and me out together, 'tis but one labour, 'tis pity she should stand ith' street, it seems she knows you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There she shall stand for me, you are ignorant; this is a common custom of the rogues that lie about the loose parts of the city.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: To knock at doors in dead time of night, and use some feigned voice to raise compassion, and when the doors are open, in they rush, and cut the throats of all and take the booty, we cannot be too careful.

sp.speaker: Within Vi.
sp.l: As ever you had pity let me in, I am undone else.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My name is Viola, a gentlewoman, that ill chance hath distressed, you know my father,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Alas of god we'll let her in, 'tis one of the gentlewomen were here ith' evening, I know her by her name, (Poor soul) she's cold I warrant her, let her have my warm bed, and I'll take her fortune; come, pray come.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is not Viola that's certain, she went home to her fathers, I am sure,

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Will not you be so good to let me in?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'll be so good to have you whipped away if you stay a little longer: she's gone I warrant her, now let me know your cause for I will hear it, and not repent the knowing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Since you are so importunate, I'll tell you, I love your wife extremely.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And so well that I dare not stay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: M●r.
sp.p: For wronging you, I know I am flesh and blood, and you have done me friendships infinite and often, that must require me honest and a true man, and I will be so or I'll break my heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why, you may stay for all this, methinks .

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, though I wood be good, I am no saint, nor is it safe to try me, I deal plainly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come I dare try you, do the best you can.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You shall not when I am right again, I'll come and see you, till when, I'll use all countries and all means, but I will lose this folly, 'tis a devil.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is there no way to stay you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, unless you will have me such a villain to you as all men shall spit at me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Does she know you love her?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No I hope not, that were recompense fit for a rogue to render her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If ever any had a faithful friend I am that man, and I may glory in't, this is he, that ipse, he that passes all Christendom for goodness, he shall not over go me in his friendship 'twere recreant and base, and I'll be hanged first, I am resolved, go thy ways, a wife shall never part us, I have considered and I find her nothing to such a friend as thou art; I'll speak a bold word, take your time and woe her, you have overcome me clearly, and do what's fitting with her, you conceive me, I am glad at heart you love her: by this light, never stare upon me for I will not fly from it, if you had spoken sooner, sure you had been served; sir, you are not every man, now to your task, I give you free leave, and the sin is mine if there be any in it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: He will be hanged before he makes this good, he cannot be so innocent a coxcomb, he can tell ten sure, if I had never known you as I have done, I might be one, as others perhaps sooner, but now 'tis impossible there's too much good between us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well thou art e'en the best man — I can say no more, I am, so over joyed, you must stay this night, and in the morning go as early as you please, I have a toy for you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I thought this pill would make you sick.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But where you mean to be I must have notice,
And it must be hard by too, do you mark me?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There is a thing in hand.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why? what thing?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A sound one, if it take right, and you be not peevish we two will be — you would little think it; as famous for our friendship —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If God please, as ever Damon was and Pytheas or Pylades, and Orestes, or any two that ever were: do you conceive me yet?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No by my troth sir; he will not help me up sure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You shall anon, and for our names, I think they shall live after us, and be remembered while there is a story; or I lose my aim.

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.l: What a vengeance ails he? how do you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes faith, we two will be such friends as the world shall ring off.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And why is all this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You shall enjoy my wife.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The wonder must begin, so I have cast it, 'twill be scurvy else, you shall not stir a foot in't, pray be quiet till I have made it perfect.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What shall a man do with this wretched fellow? there is no mercy to be used towards him, he is not capable of any pity, he will in spite of course be a cuckold, and who can help it? must it begin so needs sir? — think again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes marry must it, and I myself will woe this woman for you, do you perceive it now? ha?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes now I have a little sight i'th matter; oh that thy head should be so monstrous, that all thy servants hats may hang upon't! but do you mean to do this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes certain, I will woe her, and for you, strive not against it, 'tis the overthrow of the best plot that ever was then.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay I'll assure you sir, I'll do no harm, you have too much about you of your own.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Have you thought of a place yet?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A place?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I a place where you will bide, prithee no more of this modesty, 'tis foolish, and we were not determined to be absolute friends indeed, 'twere tolerable.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I have thought, and you shall hear from me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why? this will gain me everlasting glory; I have the better of him, that's my comfort, good night. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good night, well go thy ways, thou art the tydiest wittal this day I think above ground, and yet thy end for all this must be motley. Exit.

div.stage: Enter a tincker, with a cord, and Dorathy.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: 'Tis bitter cold; a plague upon these rogues, how wary they are grown? not a door open now, but double bard, not a window, but up with a case of wood like a spice box, and their locks unpickable, the very smith's that were half venturers, drink penitent single ale, this is the iron age, the ballad sings of; well I shall meet with some of our loose linen yet, good fellows must not starve; here's he shall show you god a mighties dog bolts, if this hold.

sp.speaker: Dorathy.
sp.p: Faith thou art but too merciful, that's thy fault thou art as sweet a thief, that sin excepted ever suffered, that's a proud word and I'll maintain it.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: Come prithee let's shogg off, and browse an hour or two, there's ale will make a cat speak, at the harrow, we shall get nothing now, without we batter, 'tis grown too near morning, the rogues sleep sober, and are watchful.

sp.speaker: Dorit.
sp.p: We want a boy extremely for this function kept under for a year, with milk and knot-grass; in my time I have seen a boy do wonders robin the red tinker had a boy rest his soul he suffered this time 4. years for two spoons, and a pewter candlestick, that sweet man had a boy as I am kirsened whore, would have run through a cat hole, he would have bolted such a piece of linen in an evening —

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: Well, we will have a boy, prithee let's go, I am vengeance cold I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Dorithy.
sp.p: I'll be hanged before I stir without some purchase by these ten bones, I'll turn she ape and untile a house, but I'll have it, it may be I have an humour to be hanged, I cannot tell

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: Peace, you flayed whore, thou hast a mouth like a Bloodhound, here comes a night shade.

sp.speaker: Dorit.
sp.p: A gentlewoman whore, by this darkness I'll case her to the skin.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.l: Peace I say.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: What fear have I endured this dismal night?
And what disgrace if I were seen and known?
In which this darkness, only is my friend,
That only has undone me; a thousand curses
Light on my easy, foolish childish, love,
That durst so lightly lay a confidence
Upon a man, so many being false;
My weariness, and weeping makes me sleepy, I must lie down.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: What's this? A prayer, or a homily, or a ballad of good council? she has a gown, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Knock out her brains and then she'll ne'er bite

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.l: Yes I will knock her, but not yet, you? woman?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: For god's sake what are you?

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: One of the grooms of your wardrobe, come uncase, uncase; by'r lady a good kersey.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Pray do not hurt me sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Let's have no pity, for if you do, here's that shall cut your whistle.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Alas what would you have? I am as miserable as you can make me any way.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That shall be tried.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Here, take my gown if that will do you pleasure.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: Yes marry will it, look in the pocket's doll, there may be birds.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: They are flown a pox go with them, I'll have this hat, and this ruff too, I like it, now will I flourish like a lady, brave i'faith boy.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: You're so gentle people to my seeming,
That by my truth I could live with you.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: Could you so? A pretty young round wench, well blooded, I am for her, thieves.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.p: But by this I am not, cool your godpiece, rogue, or I'll clap a spell upon't, shall take your edge off with a very vengeance.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: Peace horseflesh, peace, I'll cast off my Amazon, she has walked too long, and is indeed notorious, she'll fight and scold, and drink like one of the worthies.

sp.speaker: Dort.
sp.p: Uds precious you young contagious whore must you be 'ticing? and is your flesh so rank sir, that two may live upon't? I am glad to hear your curtal grown so lusty; he was dry foundered tother day, we he my pampered lade of Asia.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Good woman do not hurt me, I am sorry that I have given any cause of anger.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Either bind her quickly and come away, or by this steel I'll tell though I truss for company; now could I eat her broiled, or any way, without vinegar, I must have her nose.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: By any thing you love best, good sir, good woman.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.l: Why her nose Dorithy?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If I have it not and presently and warm, I lose that I go withal.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: Wood the devil had that thou goest withal, and thee together, for sure he got thy whelps if thou hast any, she's thy dear dad, whore! put up your cutpurse; an I take my switch up, 'twill be a black time with you else sheth your bung whore.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Will you bind her? we shall stand here prating and be hung both.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.l: Come I must bind you, not a word, no crying.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Do what you will, indeed I will not cry.

sp.speaker: Tinker
sp.p: Hurt her not, if thou dost by ale and bear I'll clout thy old bald brain pan, with a piece of brass, you bitch incarnate.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: O God to what am I reserved, that knew not
Through all my childish hours and actions
More sin than poor imagination,
And too much loving of a faithless man?
For which I am paid, and so, that not the day
That now is rising to protect the harmless,
And give the innocent a sanctuary
From thieves and spoilers, can deliver me
From shame, at least suspicion —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sirrah lead down the horses easily, I'll walk a foot till I be down the hill, 'tis very early, I shall reach home betimes. How now, who's there?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Night that was ever friend to lovers, yet
Has raised some weary soul, that hates his bed
To come and see me blush, and then laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He'd a rude heart that did this.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Gentle sir,
If you have that which honest men call pity,
And be as far from evil as you show;
Help a poor maid, that this night by bad fortune
Has been thus used by robbers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A pox upon his heart that would not help thee, this thief was half a lawyer, by his bands, how long have you been tied here?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Alas this hour, and with cold and fear am almost perished.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where were the watch the while? good sober gent. they were like careful members of the city, drawing in diligent ale and singing catches, while Mr. Constable contrived the toasts: these fellows would be more severely punished then wandering Gipsies, that every statute whips, for if they had every one two eyes a piece more, three pots would put them out.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I cannot tell I found no christian to give me succour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: When they take a thief, I'll take Ostend again; the whoresons drink opium in their ale, and then they sleep like tops; as for their bills, they only serve to reach down bacon to make rashers on; now let me know whom I have done this courtesy too, that I may thank my early rising for it?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Sir, all I am, you see.

sp.speaker: Val
sp.p: You have a name I'm sure, and a kindred, a father, friend or something that must own you; she's a handsome young wench; what rogues were these to rob her?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Sir you see all I dare reveal,
And as you are a gent press me no further;
For there begins a grief whose bitterness
Will break a stronger heart than I have in me,
And 'twill but make you heavy with the hearing,
For your own goodness' sake desire it not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If you would not have me inquire that, how do you live then?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: How I have lived, is still one question,
Which must not be resolved —
How I desire to live, is in your liking,
So worthy an opinion I have of you,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is in my liking? how I pray thee? tell me, i'faith I'll do you any good lies in my power; she has an eye would raise a bedrid man; come leave your fear and tell me, that's a good wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Sir I would serve —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who wouldst thou serve? do not weep and tell me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Faith sir even some good woman, and such a wife if you be married, I do imagine yours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Alas! thou art young and tender, let me see thy hand, this was near made to wash or wind up water, beat clothes, or rub a floor, by this light, for one use that shall be nameless, 'tis the best wanton hand that ere I look on.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Dare you accept me sir, my heart is honest,
Among your virtuous charitable deeds,
This will not be the least.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou canst in a chamber.

sp.speaker: Vio
sp.l: In a chamber sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I mean wait there upon a gentlewoman,
How quick she is, I like that mainly too;
I'll have her, though I keep her with main strength
Like a besieged town, for I know I shall have the enemy afore me within a week.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Sir I can sow too, and make pretty laces,
Dress a head handsome, teach young gentlewomen,
For in all these I have a little knowledge.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis well, no doubt I shall increase that knowledge; I like her better still, how she provokes me; pretty youngmaid you shall serve a good gentlewoman, though I say't that will not be unwilling you should please me, nor I forgetful if you do.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I am the happier.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My man shall make some shift to carry you behind him, can you ride well?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: But I'll hold fast for catching of a fall.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That's the next way to pull another on you, I'll work her as I go I know she's wax, now, now, at this time could I beget a worthy on this wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Sir for this gentleness, may heaven requite you tenfold.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis a good wench how ever others use thee, be sure I'll be a loving master to thee, come. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Antonio like an Irish footman, with a letter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I hope I am wild enough for being known I have writ a letter here, and in it have abused myself most bitterly, yet all my fear is not enough, for that must do it, that must lay it on, I'll win her out i'th flint, 'twill be more famous, now for my language.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Now sir who would you speak with?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where be thy master's man? I would speak with her.
I have a letter.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Cannot I deliver it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No by my trot and fait canst thou not man.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Well sir I'll call her to you, pray shake your ears without a little. Exit. Servingman.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Cran a Cree do it quickly; this rebel tongue sticks in my teeth worse than a tough hen, sure it was ne'er known at Babel, for they sold no apples, and this was made for certain at the first planting of orchards 'tis so crabbed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What's he wood speak with me?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: A Killkenny ring, there he stands madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What would you have with me, friend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He has a letter for other women, wilt thou read it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: De cross creest from my master.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who is your master?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I pray do you look.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do you know this fellow?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: No madam not I; more than an Irish footman stand further friend, I do not like your roperunners, what stallion rogues are these, to wear such dowsets, the very cotton may commit adultery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I cannot find whose hand this should be, I'll read, to the beauteous wife of don Antonio, sure this is some blind scrib — well now what follows?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray God it take, I have given her, that will stir her conscience, how it works with her; hope if it be thy will let the flesh have it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is the most abhorred, intolerable knavery, that ever slave entertained, sure there is more than thine own head in this villainy, it goes like practised mischief, disabled in his body? O good God, as I live he lies fearfully, and basely, ha? I should know that jewel, 'tis my husband, come hither shalt, are you an Irish man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sweet woman a Cree I am an Irish man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now I know it perfectly; is this your trick sir? I'll trick you for it; how long have you served this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Please thee a little day, oh my Mac dermond put me to my mastree, 'tis done I know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By my faith he speaks as well as if he had been lousy for the language a year or two; well sir, you had been better have kept your own shape as I will use you, what have I done that should deserve this trial, I never made him cuckold to my knowledge, sirrah come hither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now will she send some jewel, or some letter
I know her mind as well; I shall be famous.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take this Irish bawd here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And kick him till his breeches and breech be of one colour a bright blew both.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I may be well swinged thus, for I dare not reveal myself, I hope she does not mean it, oh hone oh hone, oh st. Patrick, oh a Cree, oh sweet woman.

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.l: No turn him and kick him oh tother side, that's well

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O good waiting man, I beseech thee good waiting man, a pox fire your legs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You rogue you enemy to all, but little breeches how dar'st thou come to me with such a letter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee pity the poor Irishman, all this makes for me, if I win her yet, I am still more glorious.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now could I weep at what I have done, but I'll harden my heart again, go shut him up, till my husband comes home, yet thus much ere ye go, sirrah thatched head, wouldst not thou be whipped and think it justice? well aquavitae barrel, I will bounce you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I pray do, I beseech you be not angry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O you hobby headed rascal, I'll have you flayed, and trossers made of thy skin to tumble in, go a way with him, let him see no sun, till my husband come home, sir I shall meet with you for your knavery, I fear it not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wilt thou not let me go? I do not like this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Come I'll lead you in by your jack a lent hair, go quietly or I'll make your crupper crack.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And do you hear me sirrah? and when you have done, make my coach ready.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes forsooth. Exit. Servingman with Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lock him up safe enough I'll to this gentleman,
I know the reason of all this business, for I do suspect it,
If he have this plot, I'll ring him such a peal, shall make his ears deaf for a month at least. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Am I not mad? can this weak tempered head,
That will be mad with drink, endure the wrong
That I have done a virgin and my love?
Be mad, for so thou ought'st, or I will beat
The walls and trees, down with thee, and will let
Either thy memory out or madness in,
But sure I never loved fair Viola:
I never loved my father nor my mother,
Or any thing but drink; had I had love;
Nay, had I known so much charity,
As would have saved an infant from the fire,
I had been naked, raving in the street:
With half a face, gashing myself with knives,
Two hours ere this time.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Good morrow gentlemen, shall we go drink again?
I have my wits.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: So have I but they are unsettled ones, would I had some porridge.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: The tavern boy was here this morning with me
And told me that there was a gentlewoman,
Which he took for a whore that hung on me:
For whom we quarrelled, and I know not what.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I'faith nor I.

sp.speaker: Ube.
sp.l: I have a glimmering of some such thing.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Was it you Silvio,
That made me drink so much? 'twas you or Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I know not who.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: We were all apt enough.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But I will lay the fault on none but me,
That I would be so entreated, come Silvio,
Shall we go drink again, come gentlemen,
Why do you stay, let's never leave off now,
Whilst we have wine and throats, I'll practise it,
Till I have made it my best quality;
For what is best for me to do but that?
For god's sake come and drink; when I am named
Men shall make answer, which Richado mean you?
The excellent drinker? I will have it so,
Will you go drink?

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.l: We drunk too much too lately.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why there is then the less behind to drink,
Let's end it all, dispatch that, we'll send abroad,
And purchase all the wine the world can yield,
And then drink it off, then take the fruits o'the earth,
Distil the juice from them, and drink that off;
We'll catch the rain before it fall to ground,
And drink off that that never more may grow;
We'll set our mouths to springs, and drink them off,
And all this while we'll never think of those
That love us best, more than we did last night.
We will not give unto the poor a drop
Of all this drink, but when we see them weep,
We'll run to them, and drink their tears off too,
We'll never leave whilst there is heat or moisture,
In this large globe, but suck it cold and dry,
Till we have made it elemental earth,
Merely by drinking.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Is't flattery to tell you, you are mad?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: If it be false,
There's no such way to bind me to a man;
He that will have me, lay my goods and lands,
My life down for him, need no more, but say
Richardo thou art mad, and then all these
Are at his service, than he pleases me,
And makes me think that I had virtue in me,
That I had love, and tenderness of heart,
That though I have committed such a fault,
As never creature did, yet run mad,
As honest men should do for such a crime,
I have expressed some worth, though it be late:
But I alas have none of these in me,
But keep my wits still like a frozen man,
That had no fire within him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nay good Richardo leave this wild talk, and send a letter to her, I'll deliver it.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: 'Tis to no purpose; perhaps she's lost last night,
Or she got home again, she's now so strictly
Looked to, the wind can scarce come to her, or admit
She were herself; if she would hear from me,
From me unworthy, that have used her thus,
She were so foolish, that she were no more
To be beloved. Enter servant with a nightgown.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir, we have found this nightgown she took with her.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Where? where? speak quickly.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Searching in the suburbs, we found a tinker and his whore, that had in it a sap-house, whom we apprehended, and they confessed they stole it from her.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: And murdered her?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What ail you man?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why all this doth not make me mad.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: It does, you would not offer this else, good Pedro look to his sword.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: They do deny the killing of her, but swore they left her tied to a tree, in the fields, next those suburbs that are without our lady's gate, near day, and by the road, so that some passenger must needs untie her quickly.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: The will of heaven be done? Sir I will only entreat you this, that as you were the greatest occasion of her loss, that you will be pleased to urge your friends, and be yourself earnest in the search of her; if she be found, she is yours, if she please, I myself only, see these people better examined, and after follow some way in search, God keep you gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Alas good man!

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What think you now of me, I think this lump
Is nothing but a piece of phlegm congealed
Without a soul, for where there's so much spirit
As would but warm a flea, those faults of mine
Would make it glow and flame in this dull heart,
And run like molten gold through every sin,
Till it could burst these walls and fly away.
Shall I entreat you all to take your horses,
And search this innocent?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Do not divide yourselves till you come there,
Where they say she was tied, I'll follow too,
But never to return till she be found.
Give me my sword good Pedro, I will do
No harm believe me with it, I am now
Far better tempered, if I were not so,
I have enough besides, God keep you all,
And send us good success. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Who is it? can you tell?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: By my troth sir I know not, but 'tis a gentlewoman

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A gentleman I'll lay my life you puppy, has sent his wife to me: if he have, fling up the bed.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here she is sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am glad I found you sir, there take your letter and keep it till you have another friend to wrong, 'tis too malicious false to make me sin, you have provoked me to be that I love not, a talker, and you shall hear me.
sp.l: Why should you dare to imagine me
So light a housewife, that from four hours knowledge
You might presume to offer to my credit
This rude and ruffian trial, I am sure
I never courted you, nor gave you tokens,
That might concern assurance, you are a fool.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I cannot blame you now, I see this letter
Though you be angry, yet with me you must not,
Unless you'll make me guilty of a wrong,
My worst affections hate —

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Did not you send it?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
No upon my faith, which is more, I understand
it not; the hand is as far from my knowledge, as the malice.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.l: It is so, and had been stranger, and indeed more hateful,
Had I, that have received such courtesies, and owe so many
Thanks, done this base office.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Your name is at it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, but not my nature, and I shall hate my name worse than the manner, for this base broking; you are wise and virtuous, remove this fault from me; for on the love I bear to truth and goodness, this letter dare not name me for the author.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Now I perceive my husband's knavery, if my man can but find where he has been, I will go with this gentleman whatsoever comes on't: and as I mean to carry it both he and all the world shall think it fit, and thank me for it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I must confess I loved you, at first, however this made me leave your house unmannerly, that might provoke me to do something ill, both to your honour and my faith, and not to write this letter, which I hold so truly wicked, that I will not think on't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I do believe you, and since I see you are free, my words were not meant to you, but this is not the half of my affliction.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis pity you should know more vexation; may I inquire?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Faith sir I fear I have lost my husband.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your husband? it cannot be: I pity her, how she's vexed?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: How now? what news? nay speak, for we must know.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Faith I have found at length by chance where he has been

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: In a blind outhouse in the suburbs, pray God all be well with him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: There are his clothes, but what's become of him, I cannot yet inquire.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am glad of this; sure they have murdered him, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Be not so grieved before you know the truth, you have time enough to weep, this is the sudden'st mischief; did you not bring an officer to search there, where you say you found his clothes.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes, and we searched it, and charged the fellow with him: but he like a rogue, stubborn rogue, made answer, he knew not where he was; he had been there, but where he was now, he could not tell: I tell you true I fear him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Are all my hopes and longings to enjoy him,
After this 3 years travel, come to this?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: It is the rankest house in all the city, the most cursed roguy bawdy-house? hell fire it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: This is the worst I heard yet; will you go home? I'll bear you company, and give you the best help I may: this being here will wrong you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: As you are a gentleman, and as you loved your dead friend, let me not go home, that will but heap one sorrow on another.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why purpose any thing and I'll perform't; I am at my wits end too.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: So am I, oh my dear master!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Peace you great fool.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Then good sir carry me to some retired place, far from the sight of this unhappy city, whether you will indeed, so it be far enough.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If I might council you, I think 'twere better to go home, and try what may be done yet, he may be at home afore you, who can tell?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O no, I know he's dead, I know he's murdered; tell me not of going home, you murder me too.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Well, since it pleases you to have it so, I will no more persuade you to go home, I'll be your guide in the country, as your grief doth command me, I have a mother dwelling from this place some 20. miles, the house though homely, yet able to show something like a welcome: thither I'll see you safe with all your sorrows.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: With all the speed that may be thought upon; I have a coach here ready, good sir quickly; I'll fit you my fine husband.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: It shall be so; if this fellow be dead, I see no band of any other man, to tie me from my will, and I will follow her with such careful service, that she shall either be my love or wife; will you walk in?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I thank you sir, but one word with my man, and I am ready; keep the Irish fellow safe, as you love your life, for he I fear has a deep hand in this, then search again, and get out warrants for that naughty man, that keeps the bad house, that he may answer it, if you find the body, give it due burial; farewell. You shall hear from me, keep all safe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: O my sweet Mr.!

sp.speaker: Ant. within.
sp.p: Man-a-cree, the devil take thee, wilt thou kill me here, I prithee now let me go seek my Mr. I shall be very cheel else.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Do you hear Man-a-cree, I'll cree your coxcomb, and you keep not still, down you rogue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Good sweet fact servingman, let me out I beseech de, and by my trot I will give die worship 2. shillings in good argot, to buy die worship pippins.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: This rogue thinks all the worth of man consists in pippins; by this light I'll beat rebellion out of you for ever.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Wilt thou not hear me man? is fetched, I'll give thee all I have about me.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I thank you sir, so I may have picking work,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here is five shillings man,
Here is a cudgel, a very good one.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: How now, what's the matter, where's the Irishman.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: There, a with take him, he makes more noise alone there, than ten lawyers can do with double and a scurvy case.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Let him out, I must talk with him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Wilt thou give me some drink, o hone? I am very dry man.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.p: You shall have that shall quench your thirst, my friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fate dost thou mean man.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Even a good tough halter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A halter? O hone!

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Sirrah you are a mischievous rogue, that's the truth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No fetched I am not.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: Shall I knock out his brains? I have killed dogs have been worth three of him for all uses.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.p: Sirrah, the truth on't is, you must with me to a justice. O Roger, Roger.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: Why, what's the matter William?

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Heavy news Roger, heavy news, God comfort us.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: What is't man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What's the matter now? I am e'en weary of this way, would were out on't.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: My Mr. sure is murdered, Roger, and this cursed rogue fear has had a hand in't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No fet not.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: Stand away, I'll kickt out of him: come sirrah, mount, I'll make you dance, you rascal, kill my master? If thy breech were cannon proof, having this good cause on my side, I would encounter it; hold fair, Shamrocke.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why how now sirs? you will not murder me indeed.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Bless us Roger!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, I am no spirit.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: How do you sir, this is my very master.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why well enough yet, but you have a heavy foot of your own; where's my wife?

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: Alas poor sorrowful gentlewoman, she thinks you are dead, and has given o'er housekeeping.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whether is she gone then?

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: Into the country with the gentleman your friend sir, to see if she can wear her sorrows out there; she weeps and takes on too too —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This falls out pat; I shall be everlasting for a name: do you hear? upon your lives and faiths to me, not one word I am living, but let the same report pass along, that I am murdered still; I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have a cause sir that's enough for you; well, if I be not famous, I am wronged much; for any thing I know I will not trouble him this week at least, no, let them take their way one of another.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: Sir, will you be still an Irishman. ?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes a while.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: But your worship will be beaten no more?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No I thank you William.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: In truth sir, if it must be so, I'll do it better than a stranger.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Go, you are knaves both, but I forgive you, I am almost mad with the apprehension of what I shall be, not a word I charge you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come pretty soul, we now are near our home,
And whilst our horses are walked down the hill,
Let thou and I walk here over this close:
The footway is more pleasant, 'tis a time
My pretty one, not to be wept away,
For every living thing is full of love;
Art not thou so too? hah?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Nay, there are living things empty of love,
Or I had not been here, but for myself!
Alas, I have too much.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It cannot be, that so much beauty, so much youth and grace should have too much of love.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Pray what is love? for I am full of that I do not know.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, love fair maid is an extreme desire,
That's not to be examined but fulfilled,
To ask the reason why thou art in love,
Or what might be the noblest end in love,
Would overthrow that kindly rising warmth,
That many times slides gently o'er the heart,
'Twould make thee grave, and stayed thy thoughts would be,
Like a thrice married widow, full of ends,
And void of all compassion, and to fright thee
From such enquiry, whereas thou art now
Living in ignorance, mild, fresh, and sweet,
And but sixteen, the knowing what love is,
Would make thee six and forty.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Would it would make me nothing, I have heard
Scholars affirm the world is upheld by love,
But I believe women maintain all this,
For there's no love in men.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, in some men.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I know them not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, there is love in me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: There's charity I am sure towards me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And love; which I will now express, my pretty maid,
I dare not bring thee home, my wife is foul,
And therefore envious, she is very old,
And therefore jealous; thou art fair and young,
A subject fit, for her unlucky vices.
To work upon, she never will endure thee.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: She may endure
If she be ought, but devil, all the friendship
That I will hold with you; can she endure
I should be thankful to you? may I pray
For you and her, will she be brought to think
That all the honest industry I have
Deserves brown bread? if this may be endured,
She'll pick a quarrel with a sleeping child,
Ere she fall out with me.

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: But trust me she does hate all handsomeness.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: How fell you in love with such a creature?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I never loved her.

sp.speaker: Vio,
sp.l: And yet married her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She was a rich one.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And you swore I warrant you, she was a fair one then too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Or believe me I think I had not had her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Are you men all such? wood you wood wall us in a place
Where all we women, that are innocent,
Might live together.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do not weep at this,
Although I dare not for some weighty reason
Displease my wife, yet I forget not thee.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What will you do with me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou shalt be placed
At my man's house, and have such food and raiment
As can be bought with money: these white hands
Shall never learn to work, but they shall play
As thou sayest they were wont, teaching the strings
To move in order, or what else thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I thank you sir, but pray you clothe me poorly,
And let my labour get me means to live.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But fair one, you I know do so much hate
A foul ingratitude, you will not look
I should do this for nothing.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I will work as much out as I can, and take as little
That you shall have as duly paid to you
As ever servant did.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But give me now a trial on't, I may believe
We are alone, show me how thou wilt kiss
And hug me hard, when I have stolen away
From my too clamorous wife that watches me,
To spend a blessed hour or two with thee.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Is this the love you mean? you would have that
Is not in me to give, you would have lust.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not to dissemble, or to mince the word,
'Tis lust I wish indeed.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And by my troth I have it not for heaven's sake use me kindly.
Though I be good, and show perhaps a monster,
As this world goes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do
But speak to thee, thy answers are thy own,
I compel none, but if thou refuse this motion,
Thou art not then for me, alas good soul?
What profit can thy work bring me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: But I fear: I pray go, for lust they say will grow
Outrageous being denied, I give you thanks
For all your courtesies, and there's a jewel
That's worth the taking, that I did preserve
Safe from the robbers, pray you leave me here
Just as you found me, a poor innocent,
And heaven will bless you for it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pretty maid I am no robber nor no ravisher,
I pray thee keep thy jewel, I have done
No wrong to thee, though thou beest virtuous
And in extremity, I do not know,
That I am bound to keep thee.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: No sir, for god's sake if you know an honest man in all these countries, give me some directions to find him out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: More honest than myself good sooth I do not know; I would have lain with thee with thy consent, and who would not in all these parts, is passed my memory, I am sorry for thee, farewell gentle maid, god keep thee safe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I thank you sir, and you;
Woman they say, was only made of man,
Methinks 'tis strange they should be so unlike,
It may be all the best was cut away
To make the woman and the naught was left
Behind with him, I'll sit me down and weep,
All things have cast me from 'em but the earth;
The evening comes and every little flower
Droops now, as well as I.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Good Madge let's rest a little, by my troth I am weary, this new pail is a plaguy heavy one, would Tom were hanged for choosing it, 'tis the antowardst fool in a country.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: With all my heart, and I thank you too, Nan.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What true contented happiness dwells here,
More than in cities? wood to God my father
Had lived like one of these and bred me up
To milk and do as they do: methinks
'Tis a life that I wood choose, if I were now
To tell my time again, above a princes; maids for charity
Give a poor wench one draught of milk
That weariness and hunger have nigh famished.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If I had but one cow's milk in all the world, you should have some on't; there drink more, the cheese shall pay for it, alas poor heart! she's dry.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Do you dwell hereabouts ?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: No, would I did.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Madge if she do not look like my cousin sue o'th more lane as one thing can look like another —

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay sue has a hazel eye, I know sue well, and by your leave not so trim a body neither, this is a feat bodied thing I tell you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: She laces close by the mass I warrant you, and so does sue too.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I thank you for your gentleness fair maids.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Drink again pray thee.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I am satisfied, and heaven reward thee for't, yet thus far I will compel you to accept these trifles, toys only that express my thanks, for greater worth, I'm sure they have not in them; indeed you shall, I found 'em as I came.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Madge, look you here Madge.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay I have as fine a one as you, mine's all gold and painted, and precious stone in't; I warrant it cost a crown wench.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: But mine is the most sumptuous one that ere I saw.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: One favour you must do me more, for you are well acquainted here.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Indeed we'll do you any kindness sister.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Only to send me to some honest place, where I may find a service.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Uds me, our Dorithy went away but last week and I know my mistress wants a maid, and why may she not be placed there? this is a likely wench I tell you truly, and a good wench I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: And 'tis a hard case if we that have served four years a piece cannot bring in one servant, we will prefer her; hark you sister, pray what's your name?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Melvia.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: A feat name i'faith, and can you milk a cow? and make a merry-bush? that's nothing.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I shall learn quickly.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And dress a house with flowers? and serve a pig? this you must do, for we deal in the dairy, and make a bed or two?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I hope I shall.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But be sure to keep the men out, they will mar all that you make else, I know that by myself; for I have been so toused among 'em in my days, come you shall e'en home with us and be our fellow, our house is so honest, and we serve a very good woman, and a gentlewoman, and we live as merrily, and dance a good days after evensong, our wake shall be on Sunday; do you know what a wake is? we have mighty cheer then, and such a coil, 'twould bless ye; you must not be so bashful, you'll spoil all.

sp.speaker: Mag.
