sp.p: Let's home for God's sake, my mistress thinks by this time we are lost, come we'll have a care of you, I warrant you; but you must tell my mistress where you were born, and every thing that belongs to you, and the strangest things you can devise, for she loves those extremely, 'tis no matter whether they be true or no, she's not so scrupulous; you must be our sister, and love us best, and tell us every thing, and when cold weather comes we'll lie together, will you do this?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Then home again a god's name, can you go apace.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I warrant you. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: How now, any good news yet?

sp.speaker: Silvio.
sp.l: Faith not any yet.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This comes a tippling; would 'twere treason and pleased God to drink more than three draughts at a meal.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: When did you see Richardo?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I crossed him twice today.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You have heard of a young wench that was seen last night?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Has Richard hard of this?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes and I think he's ridden after, farewell I'll have another round.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: If you hear any thing, pray spare no horseflesh
I'll do the like.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Do.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sir, I did think 'twas you by all descriptions.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis so,
I took her up indeed, the manner how
You have heard already, and what she had about her,
As jewels, gold and other trifling things:
And what my end was, which because she slighted,
I left her there i'the fields.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Left i'th fields? could any but a rogue
That had despised humanity and goodness,
God, law and credit? and had set himself
To lose his noblest part, and be a beast,
Have left so innocent, unmatched a virtue,
To the rude mercy of a wilderness?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir if you come to rail, pray quit my house,
I do not use to have such language given;
Within my doors to me; for your wench,
You may go seek her with more patience,
She's tame enough I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Pray forgive me.
I do confess my much forgetfulness;
And weigh my words no farther I beseech you,
Than a mere madness; for such a grief has seized me
So strong and deadly, as a punishment,
And a just one too,
That 'tis a greater wonder I am living,
Than any thing I utter; yet let me tell you thus much,
'Twas a fault for leaving her
So in the fields.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir I will think so now, and credit me,
You have so wrought me with your grief, that I
Do both forgive and pity you:
And if you'll please to take a bed this night here;
Too morrow I'll bring you where I left her.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I thank you, no, shall I be so unworthy,
To think upon a bed, or ease or comfort,
And have my heart stray from me God knows where,
Cold and forsaken, destitute of friends,
And all good comforts else, unless some tree
Whose speechless charity must better ours,
With which the bitter East winds made their sport
And sung through hourly, hath invited her
To keep off half a day? shall she be thus,
And I draw in soft slumbers? God forbid.
No, night and bitter coldness I provoke thee,
And all the dews that hang upon thy locks,
Showers, hails, snows, frosts, and two edged winds that prime
The maiden blossoms, I provoke you all,
And dare expose this body to your sharpness,
Till I be made a land mark.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you then stay and eat with me?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: You're angry with me, I know you're angry,
You would not bid me eat else; my poor mistress,
For ought I know thou art famished, for what else
Can the fields yield thee, and the stubborn season,
That yet holds in the fruit? good gentle sir,
Think not ill manners in me for denying
Your offered meat, for sure I cannot eat
While I do think she wants; well I'm a rascal;
A villain, slave, that only was begotten,
To murder women and of them the best.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is a strange affliction.
If you'll accept no greater courtesy, yet drink sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now I am sure you hate me, and you knew
What kind of man I am, as indeed 'tis fit,
That every man should know me to avoid me.
If you have peace within you sir, or goodness
Name that abhorred word drink no more unto me,
You had safer strike me.
I pray you do not, if you love me do not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, I mean no ill by it.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: It may be so,
Nor let me see
None sir, if you love heaven;
You know not what offence it is unto me,
Nor good now, do not ask me why:
And I warn you once again, let no man else speak of't,
I fear your servants will be prating to me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why sir what ail you?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I hate drink, there's the end on't,
And that man that drinks with meat is damned
Without an age of prayers and repentance,
And there's a hazard too; good sir no more,
If you will do me a free courtesy;
That I shall know for one, go take your horse,
And bring me to the place where you left her:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Since you are so importunate I will;
But I will wish sir you had stayed tonight
Upon my credit, you shall see no drink.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Be gone the heating of it makes me giddy,
Sir will you be entreated to forbear it,
I shall be mad else.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I pray no more of that, I am quiet,
I'll but walk in and away straight.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Now I thank you,
But what you do, do in a twinkling, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As soon as may be. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Is this the wench? you have brought me some catch I warrant;
How injuringly she looks upon the matter?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.l: Yes forsooth this is the maiden.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Come hither, wood you serve?

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: If it shalt please you to accept my service I hope I shall do something that shall like you, though it be but truth, and often praying for you.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: You are very curious of your hand methinks ,
You preserve it so with gloves, let me see it;
I marry, here's a hand of marchpane wenches:
This pretty palm never knew sorrow yet;
How soft it is I warrant you, and supple:
On my word this is fitter for a pocket to filch withal
Then to work, I fear me little one,
You are no better than you should be; go too.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: My conscience yet is but one witness to me,
And that heaven knows is or mine innocence,
'Tis true, I must confess, with shame enough,
The time that I have led yet never taught me
What was to break a sleep, or to be weary.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: You can say well: if you be mine, wench, you must do well too, for words are but slow workers, yet so much hope I have of you, that I'll take you so you'll be diligent, and do your duty: how now?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: There is a messenger come from your son
That brings you word he is returned from travel,
And will be here this night.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Now joy upon thee for it, thou art ever
A bringer of good tidings, there, drink that:
In troth thou hast much contented me, my son?
Lord how thou hast pleased me, shall I see my son
Yet ere I die? take care my house be handsome,
And the new stools set out, and boughs and rushes,
And flowers for the window, and the Turkey carpet,
And the great parcel salt, Nan, with the cruets,
And prithee Alexander go to the cook,
And bid him spare for nothing, my son's come home,
Who's come with him?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I hear of none yet, but a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: A gentlewoman? what gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I know not but such a one there is, he says.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Pray God he have not cast away himself
Upon some snout-fair piece, I do not like it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No sure, my master has more discretion.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Well, be it how it will, he shall be welcome.
Sirs, to your tasks, and show this little novice
How to bestir herself, I'll sort out things. Exit.

sp.speaker: Madg.
sp.p: We will forsooth, I can tell you my mistress is a stirring woman.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Lord how she'll talk some times? 'tis the maddest cricket —

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: methinks she talks well, and shows a great deal of good housewifry, pray let me deck the chambers, shall I?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes you shall, but do not scorn to be advised sister, for there belongs more to that than you are aware on; why would you venture so fondly upon the strowings? there's mighty matters in them I'll assure you, and in the spreading of a bough pot, you may miss if you were ten years elder, if you take not a special care before you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I will learn willingly, if that be all.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Sirrah where is't they say my young master hath been?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Faith I know not, beyond the sea, where they are born without noses.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Less bless us! without noses? how do they do for handkerchiefs?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: So Richard says, and sirrah, their feet stands in their foreheads.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: That's fine by my troth, these men have pestilence running heads then; do they speak as we do?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: No, they never speak.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Are they kirsened?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: No they call them infidels, I know not what they are.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Sirrah we shall have fine courting now my young master is come home, were you never courted sister?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Alas I know it not.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What is that courting sirrah?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I can tell, for I was once courted in the matted chamber, you know the party Madge, faith he courted finely.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Pray thee what is't?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Faith nothing but he was some what figent with me, faith 'tis fine sport, this courting.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Where be the maids there?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: We shall be hanged anon, away good wenches, and a care you dight things handsomely, I will look over you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If your sorrow will give you so far leave, pray think yourself most welcome to this place, for so upon my life you are, and for your own fair sake, take truce a while with these immoderate mournings.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thank you sir, I shall do what I may;
Pray lead me to a chamber.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Presently,
Before your blessing mother, I entreat ye
To know this gentlewoman, and bid her welcome,
The virtuous wife of him that was myself
In all my travels.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Indeed she is most welcome, so are you sonKneel.
Now all my blessing on thee; thou hast made me
Younger by 20 years, than I was yesterday,
Will you walk in? what ails this gentlewoman?
Alas I fear she is not well, good gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You fear right.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: She has fasted over long,
You shall have supper presently o'th board.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She will not eat I can assure you mother,
For god's sake let your maid conduct her up
Into some fair becoming chamber
Fit for a woman of her being and
As soon as may be,
I know she's very ill, and wood have rest.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: There is one ready for her, the blue chamber.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I'll lead you to your chamber door
And there I'll leave you to your quiet, mistress.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thank you sir, good rest to every one,
You'll see me once again tonight I hope. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: When you shall please, I'll wait upon you lady.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Where are these maids attend upon the gentlewoman, and see she want no good thing in the house? goodnight with all my heart forsooth, good lord how you are grown? is he not Alexander?

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Yes truly he's shot up finely god be thanked.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: An ill weed mother will do so.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: You say true sir, an ill weed grows a pace.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Allexander the sharp, you take me very quickly.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Nay I can tell, Allexander will do it, do you read madcap still?

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Some times forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: But faith son what countries have you travelled?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why many, mother, as they lay before me, France, Spain, Italy and Germany, and other provinces that I am, sure you are not bettered by, when you hear of them.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: And can you these tongues perfectly?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Of some a little, mother.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Pray spout some French son.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You understand it not, and to your ears 'twill go like an unshod cart upon the stones, only a rough unhandsome sound.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Faith I would fain hear some French.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Good sir speak some French to my mistress.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: At your entreaty Allexander, I will, who shall speak to?

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: If your worship will do me the favour sir, to me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Monsieur, poltroon, cuckoo, Cullione, besay, man cur.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Awe monsieur.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, this fine indeed, god's blessing 'On thy heart son, by my troth thou art grown a proper gentleman, cullen and pullen, good god what saucey words they use beyond the seas, ha, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Did not you swear right?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes good Allexander, if you had done so to
But good mother I am very hungry and have rid far today and am fasting.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: You shall have your supper presently my sweet son.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: As soon as you please, which once ended,
I'll go and visit you sick gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Come then. Exeun. t.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, like a post, with a letter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have ridden like a fury to make up this work and I will do it bravely ere I leave it, this is the house I am sure.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Who'd you speak with sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Marry sir I would speak with a gentlewoman, came this night late here from the city, I have some letters of importance to her, I am a post sir and would be dispatched in haste.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Sir, cannot I deliver 'em? for the truth is she's ill and in her chamber.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray pardon me I must needs speak with her, my business is so weighty.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: I'll tell her so, and bring you present word.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray do so, and I'll attend her, pray god the grief of my imagined death spoil not what I intend, I hope it will not.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.l: Though she be very ill, and desires no trouble,
Yet if your business be so urgent, you may come up and speak with her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I thank you sir, I follow you. Exit. Allex.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What should this fellow be i'th name of heaven that comes with such post business? sure my husband hath revealed himself, and in this haste sent after me, are you the post my friend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes for sooth mistress.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What good news hast thou brought me gentle post?
For I have woe and grief too much already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I would you had less, mistress, I could wish it, beshrew my heart she moves me cruelly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Have I found you once more juggler? well jewel, thou hast only virtue in thee, of all I read of yet; what ears has this ass to betray him with? well, what's your business then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have brought a letter from your servant, mistress, in haste.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray give it me, I hope the best still.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is the upshot and I know I have hit it,
Well if the spirits of the dead do walk, I shall
Hear more of this one hundred years hence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By any means you must have special care, for now the city is possessed for certain, my master is made away, which for ought I know is a truth indeed; good mistress leave your grief and see your danger, and let that wise and noble gentleman with whom you are, be your right hand in all things.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now do I know I have the better on't by the languishing of her eye at this near instant, 'tis still simming in her blood, in coining somewhat to turn Mercury I know it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He is my husband, and 'tis reasonable he should command in all things, since he will be an ass again the hair at his one peril be it, in the morn you shall have a packet, till I must entreat you stay, you shall not lose by it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I do not doubt it, mistress; I'll leave you to your rest and wait your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Do, and speak out the gentleman of the house, bid him come to me presently.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who, Mr. Mercury?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Do you know him, post?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Only by sight forsooth, now I remember your servant willed me to let you know he is the only man, you and your fortunes, are now to rest upon.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Prithee no more, I know all this already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'll take my leave now, I am made for ever. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Good night I am provided for you my fine youth

div.stage: Enter mother beating Viola, Allexander, with a broken glass.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: I'll make thee have more care.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Good mistress pardon me.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Thou'lt ne'er be good I warrant thee, can your fine fingers hold no faster?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Indeed it was against my will.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Allexander, let's see the glass, as, I am true kirsome woman, it is one of the crystal glasses my cousin sent me and the baggage hath broke it where it cannot be mended, Allexander, can Humphrey mend this think you?

sp.speaker: All●x.
sp.p: No truly this will ne'er be mended.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Truly I meant but to wash it for the gentlewoman, that is sick above, and shaking out the water, knocked it against the pail side.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Did you so? be sure I'll stop it, 'twill make a good gap in your quarters wages, can tell you.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: I pray forgive me, and let me have no wages this first quarter.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Go whimling, and fetch two or three grating loaves out of the kitchen, to make gingerbread of, 'tis such an untoward thing. Exit. Viola.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: She's somewhat simple indeed, she knew not what a kimnell was, she wants good nurture mightily.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: My son tells me, Allexander, that this young widow means to sojourn here, she offers largely for her board, I may offer her good cheer, pray thee make a step i'th morning down to the parsonage for some pigeons? what are you mad there; what noise is that? are you at bowls within? why do you whine?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: I have done another fault, I beseech you sweet mistress forgive me.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: As I was reaching for the bread that lay upon the shelf, I have thrown down the minced meat, that should have made the pies tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Get thee out of my house thou filthy destroying harlot, thou, I'll not keep thee an hour longer.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Good mistress beat me rather for my fault as much as it deserves, I do not know whether to go.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: No I warrant thee, out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Indeed I'll mend, I pray speak you for me.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: If thou hadst hurled down any thing but the pie meat, I would have spoke for thee, but I cannot find in my heart now.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Art thou here yet? I think I must have an officer to thrust thee out of my doors, must I?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: Why you may stop this in my wages too,
For god's sake do, I'll find myself this year;
And let me stay.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thou'lt spoil ten times as much, I'll cudgel thee out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: I am assured you are more merciful,
Then thus to beat me and discharge me too.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Dost thou dispute with me, Allexander carry the prating hilding forth.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: Good mistress hear me I have here a jewel,
My mother left me and 'tis something worth:
Receive it and when all my faults together
Come to the worth of that, then turn me forth,
Till then I pray you keep me.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: What giggombob have we here? pray god you have not pilfered this somewhere ; thou'rt such a puling thing, wipe your eyes, and rise go your ways, Allexander, bid the cook mince some more meat, come and get you to bed quickly that you may up betime i'th morning a milking or you and I shall fall out worse yet.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: She has hurt my arm; I am afraid , she is a very angry woman, but bless him heaven that did me the most wrong, I am afraid antonious wife should see me, she will know me

sp.speaker: Mother within.
sp.p: Melvia.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: I am coming, she's not angry again I hope. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Now what am I the better for enjoying
This woman that I loved? so all I find,
That I before imagined to be happy:
Now I have done, it turns to nothing else
But a poor pitied and a base repentance,
Udsfoote I am monstrous angry with myself:
Why should a man that has discourse and reason,
And knows how near he loses all in these things,
Covet to have his wishes satisfied;
Which when they are, are nothing but the shame
I do begin to loathe this woman strangely,
And I think justly too, that durst adventure,
Flinging away her modesty to take
A stranger to her bed, her husband's body
Being scarce cold in the earth for her content,
It was no more to take my senses with,
Then if I had an idle dream had in sleep
Yet I have made her promises: which grieves me,
And I must keep 'em too, I think she hunts me:
The devil cannot keep these women off,
When they are fletched once.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: To bed for god's sake sir, why do you stay here?
Some are up i'th house, I hard the wife,
Good dear sweet heart to bed.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Why I am going? why do you follow me?
You would not have it known I hope, pray get you
Back to your chamber, the doors hard by for me,
Let me alone I warrant you, this it is
To thresh well, have got a customer,
Will you go to bed?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Will you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes I am going.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Then remember your promise you made to marry me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I will, but it was your fault, that it came
To this pinch now, that it must need remembrance:
For out of honesty I offered you
To marry you first, why did you slack that offer?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas I told you the inconvenience of it,
And what wrong it would appear to the world
If I had married you in such post haste
After his death: beside, the foolish people
Would have been bold to have thought we had lyen
Together in his time, and like enough imagined
We two had murdered him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I love her tongue yet,
If I were a saint
A gilded saint, and such a thing as this
Should prate thus wittily and feelingly
Unto my holiness, I cannot tell,
But I fear shrewdly I should do something
That would quite scratch me out o'the calendar,
And if I stay longer talking with her,
Though I am mad at what I have done already,
Yet I shall forget myself again;
I feel the devil
Ready to hold my stirrup; pray to bed, goodnight.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This kiss, goodnight sweet love,
And peace go with thee: thou hast proved thyself
The honestest man that ever was enticed
To that sweet sin as people please to call it,
Of lying with another's wife, and I,
I think the honestest woman without blushing,
That ever lay with another man, I sent my husband
Into a cellar, post, fearing, and justly,
He should have known him, which I did not purpose
Till I had had my end.
Well, now this plot is perfect, let him brag on't.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter justice, and Curio with a paper.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: By’r lady sir you have rid hard that you have.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: They that have business must do so I take it.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: You say true, when set you out my friend?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: About ten o'clock and I have rid all night.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: By the mass you are tough indeed, I have seen the day, I would have rid too with the proudest of them and fling dirt in their faces, and I have don't with this foolish boy sir many a time; but what can last always? 'tis done, 'tis done now sir, age, care, and office, brings us to our foot-cloths, the more the pity.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.p: I believe that sir, but will it please you to read the business?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: My friend I can read an I can tell you when.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Would I could too sir, for my haste requires it.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Whence comes it do you say?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Sir from the city.

sp.speaker: Justice.
sp.p: O from the city 'tis a reverent place.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.l: And his justice be as short as his memory,
A dudgeon dagger will serve him to mow down sin withal,
What clod pole commissioner is this?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: And by my faith governed by worthy member,
Discreet and upright.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.p: Sir they are beholding to you, you have given some of them a commendations, they were not worthy of this twenty years.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Go to go to, you have a merry meaning, I have found you sir i'faith, you are a wag, away, fie, now I'll read your letter.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.l: Pray do sir; what a misery 'tis,
To have an urgent business, wait the justice,
Of such an old tough taffety that knows not,
Nor can be brought to understand more sense,
Then how to restore suppressed alehouses,
And have his man compound small trespasses,
For ten groats.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Sir it seems here your business is of deeper circumstance than I conceived it for; what do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: 'Tis for mine own ease I'll assure your worship.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: It shall not be i'faith friend, here I have it,
That one Antonio a gentleman, I take it so,
Yes it is so, a gentleman is lately thought to
Have been made away, and by my faith upon a
Pearl's ground too, if you consider; well, there's
Knavery in't, I see that without spectacles.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Sure this fellow deals in revelation he's so hidden,
Go thy ways, thou wilt sick a bench spit as formally,
And show thy agate, and hatched chain
As well as the best of them.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: And now I have considered, I believe it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: That he was murdered.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Did you know him?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Nor how it is supposed.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p:
No, nor I care not twopence, those are toys and yet I verily believe he was murdered, as sure as I believe thou art a man, I never failed in these things yet, wear a man that's beaten to these matters, experience is a certain concealed thing that fails not; pray let me ask you one
thing, why do you come to me?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Because the letter is addressed to you, being the nearest justice.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: The nearest? is that all?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I think it be sir, I would be loath you should be the wisest.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Well sir, as it is, I will endeavour in it; yet if it had come to me by name, I know not, but I think it had been as soon dispatched as by another, and with as round a wisdom, ay, and as happily, but that's all one: I have born this place this thirty years, and upwards, and with sufficient credit: and they may when they please, know me better; to the nearest? well.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.p: Sir, it is not my fault, for had I known you sooner —

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I thank you sir, I know it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I'll be sworn you should have played for any business now.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: And further, they have specified unto me, his wife is sorely suspected in this matter, as a main cause,

sp.speaker: Curio
sp.p: I think she be sir, for no other cause can be yet found.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: And one Mercury a traveller, with whom they say directly she is run away, and as they think this way.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I knew all this before.

sp.speaker: Justice.
sp.p: Well sir, this Mercury I know, and his breeding, a neighbour's child hard by, you have been happy sir in coming hither.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Then you know where to have him sir?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I do sir, he dwells near me.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I doubt your worship dwells near a knave then.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I think so; pray put on: but 'tis a wonder
To see how graceless people are now given,
And how base virtue is accounted with them
That should be all in all as says a wise man.
sp.p: I tell you sir, and it is true, that there have been such murders, and of late days, as 'twould make your very heart bleed in you, and some of them as I shall be enabled I will tell you, it fell out of late days.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It may be so, but will it please you to proceed in this?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: An honest weaver, and as good a workman as ere shot shuttle, and as close: but every man must die; this honest weaver being a little mellow in his ale, that was the evidence verbatim, sir, God bless the mark, sprung his neck just in this place: well Jarvis, thou hadst wrongs, and if I live some of the best shall sweat fort, than a wench —

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: But sir you have forgotten my business.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: A sober pretty maid about 17. they say, certainly howsoever 'tis shuffled, she burst herself, and fondly, if it be so, with furmety at a churching, but I think the devil had another agent in't: either of which if I can catch shall stretch for't.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: This is a mad justice that will hang the devil; but I would you would be short in this, before that other notice can be given?

sp.speaker: Justice.
sp.p: Sir I will do discreetly what is fitting; what, Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Within.your worship?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Put on your best coat, and let your fellow mark go to the constable and bid him aid me with all the speed he can, and all the power, and provide pen and ink to take their confessions, and my long sword, I cannot tell what danger we may meet with; you'll go with us?

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.p: Yes, what else? I came to that end to accuse both parties.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: May I crave what you are?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Faith sir one that to be known would not profit you, more than a mere kinsman of the dead Antonio's.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: 'Tis well, I am sorry for my neighbour, truly, that he had no more grace, 'twill kill his mother; she's a good old woman, will you walk in? I'll but put my cloak on, and my chain off, and a clean band, and have my shoes blacked over, and shift my jerkin, and we'll to our business, and you shall see how I can bolt these matters.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: As soon as't please you sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is the place; here did I leave the maid
Alone last night drying her tender eyes,
Uncertain what to do, and yet desirous
To have me gone.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: How rude are all we men,
That take the name of civil to ourselves?
If she had set her foot upon an earth
Where people live that we call barbarous;
Though they had had no house to bring her too,
They would have spoiled the glory that the spring
Has decked the trees in, and with willing hands
Have torn their branches down, and every man
Would have become a builder for her sake.
What time left you her there?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I left her, when the sun had so much to set,
As he is now got from his place of rise.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: So near the night she could not wander far;
Fair Viola?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is in vain to call, she sought a house
Without all question.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Peace, fair Viola?
Fair Viola? who should have left her here
On such a ground? if you had meant to lose her,
You might have found there were no inches here
To take her name and carry it about,
When her true lover came to mourn for her,
Till all the neighbouring valleys and the hills,
Resounded Viola, —
And such a place,
You should have chose —
You pity us because
The dew a little wets our feet,
Unworthy far to seek her in the wet;
And what becomes of her? where wandered she,
With 2 showers raining on her, from her eyes
Continually, abundantly, from which
There's neither tree nor house to shelter her;
Will you go with me to travel?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Over all the world.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No by my faith, I'll make a shorter journey
When I do travel.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But there's no hope
To gain my end in any shorter way.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, what's your end?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: It is to search the earth,
Till we have found two in the shapes of men,
As wicked as ourselves.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Twere not so hard to find out those.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why, if we find them out,
It were the better; for what brave villainy,
Might we 4. do? we wood not keep together:
For every one has treachery enough
For 20. Countries, one should trouble Asia,
Another should sow strife in Africa;
But you should play the knave, at home in Europe,
And for America let me alone.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Sir I am honesty,
Than you know how to be, and can no more
Be wronged but I shall find myself a right.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: If you had any spark of honesty,
You would not think that honester than I,
Were a praise high enough to serve your turn:
If men were commonly so bad as I,
Thieves would be put in calendars for saints;
And bones of murderers would work miracles.
I am a kind of knave, of knave so much —
There is betwixt me and the vilest else,
But the next place of all to mine is yours.

div.stage: Enter 2. Milkemaides, and Viola, with pails.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That last is she, 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Let us away, we shall infect her, let her have the wind,
And we will kneel down here.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: Wenches away for here are men.

sp.speaker: Valerio.
sp.l: Fair maid I pray you stay.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Alas, again?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why do you lay hold on her? I pray heartily let her go.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With all my heart, I do not mean to hurt her.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But stand away then for the purest bodies
Will soonest take infection, stand away,
But for infecting her myself, by heaven,
I would come there and beat thee further off.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: I know that voice and face.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are finely mad, good-bye sir, now you are here together, I'll leave you so, god send you good luck, both when you are soberer, you'll give me thanks. Exit.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Wilt thou go milk? come.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Why dost not come?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: She nods, she's asleep .

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What, wert up so early?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: I think your man's mad to kneel there, nay come away ves body, Nan, help she looks black ith' face, she's in a sound.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And you be a man come hither, and help a woman.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Come thither? you are a fool.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And you a knave and a beast that you are.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Come hither? 'twas being my now so near,
That made her swoon, and you are wicked people,
Or you wood do so too, my venom eyes
Strike innocency dead at such a distance,
Here I'll kneel for this is out of distance.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Thou'rt a prating ass there's no goodness in thee,
I warrant, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why? well.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Art thou able to go?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: No, pray go you and milk, if I be able to come
I'll follow you, if not I'll sit here,
Till you come back.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am loath to leave thee here with you wild fool.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I know him well, I warrant thee, he will not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Come then Nan. Exeunt maids.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: How do you? be not fearful, for I hold my hands
Before my mouth and speak, and so
My breath can never blast you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: 'Twas enough to use me ill, though you had never sought me too mock me to, why kneel you so far off, were not that gesture better used in prayer, had dealt so with you, I should not sleep, till God and you had both forgiven me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I do not mock, nor lives there such a villain
That can do any thing contemptible,
To you, but I do kneel because it is,
An action very fit, and reverent,
In presence of so pure a creature,
And so far off, as fearful to offend,
One too much wronged already.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: You confess you did the fault, yet scorn to come,
So far as hither to ask pardon for't;
Which I could willingly afford to come,
To you to grant, good sir if you have
A better love, may you be blessed together,
She shall not wish you better than I will,
I but offend you; there are all the jewels
I stole, and all the love I ever had,
I leave behind with you, I'll carry now
To give another, may the next maid you try
Love you no worse, nor be no worse than I.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Do not leave me yet for all my fault,
Search out the next things too impossible,
And put me on them when they are effected,
I may with better modesty receive
Forgiveness from you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I will set no penance,
To gain the great forgiveness you desire:
But to come hither and take me and it,
Or else I'll come and beg so you will grant,
That you will be content to be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay I will come since you will have it so,
And since you please to pardon me I hope
Free from infection, here I am by you;
A careless man, a breaker of my faith,
A loathsome drunkard and in that wild fury:
A hunter after whores I do beseech you,
To pardon all these faults, and take me up
An honest sober and a faithful man.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: For god's sake urge your faults no more, but mend,
All the forgiveness I can make you is,
To love you which I will do and desire,
Nothing but love again, which if I have not,
Yet I will love you still.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: O women that some one of you will take,
An everlasting pen into your hands:
And grave in paper which the writ shall make,
More lasting than the marble monuments,
Your matchless virtues to posterities:
Which the defective race of envious man,
Strive to conceal.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Methinks I would not now for any thing,
But you had missed me, I have made a story,
Will serve to waste many a winter's fire
When we are old, I'll tell my daughters then,
The miseries their mother had in love:
And say my girls be wiser, yet I would not
Have had more wit myself, take up those jewels,
For I think I hear my fellows coming.

div.stage: Enter the milkemaides with their pails.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.l: How dost thou now?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why? very well I thank you, 'tis late shall I haste home?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: I prithee we shall be shent soundly.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.l: Why does that railing man go with us?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I preythee speak well of him, on my word,
He's an honest man.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: There was never any so one's complexion, a gentleman?
I'd be ashamed to have such a foul mouth. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter mother, Alexander, Andrugio, and his man Rowland.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: How now Alexander, what gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Indeed forsooth I know not, I found him at the market full of woe, crying a lost daughter, and telling all her tokens to the people; and wot you what? by all subscription in the world, it should be our new maid Melvia, one would little think it, therefore I was bold to tell him of her mistress.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: Melvia? it cannot be, fool, alas you know she is a poor wench, and I took her in upon mere charity.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: So seemed my daughter when she went away, as she had made herself.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: What stature was your child of, sir?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Not high, and of a brown complexion, her hair aborne, a round face, which some friends that flattered me, would say 'twould be a good one.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: This is still Melvia, mistress, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: It may be so I'll promise you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, the flower of our town, for a hand and a foot, I shall never see thy fellow.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: But had she not such toys, as bracelets, rings, and jewels?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: She was something bold indeed, to take such things that night she left me.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Then belike she run away?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Though she be one I love, I dare not lie, she did indeed.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: What think you of this jewel?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Yes, this was one of them, and this was mine, you have made me a new man, I thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Nay, and she be given to filching, there is your jewel, I am clear on't: but by your leave sir, you shall answer me for what is lost since she came hither, can tell you there lie things scattering in every place about the house.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As I am virtuous, I have the lyingst old gentlewoman to my mistress, and the most malicious, the devil a good word will she give a servant, that's her old rule; and God be thanked they'll give her as few, there is perfect love on both sides, it yearns my heart to hear the wench misconstrued, a careful soul she is I'll be sworn for her, and when she's gone, let them say what they will, they may cast their caps at such another.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: What you have lost by her, with all my heart
I'll see you double paid, for you have saved
With your kind pity two that must not live
Unless it be to thank you; take this jewel,
This strikes off none of her offences, mistress,
Would I might see her.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Alexander, run, and bid her make haste home, she's at the milking close; but tell her not by any means who's here, I know she'll be too fearful.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Well, we'll have a posset yet at parting, that's my comfort, and one round, or else I'll lose my will.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: You shall find Silvio, Uberto, and Pedro enquiring for the wench at the next town, tell them she is found, and where I am, and with the favour of this gentlewoman, desire them to come hither,

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: I pray do, they shall be all welcome. Exit servant.

sp.speaker: Justice.
sp.p: By your leave forsooth you shall see me find the parties by a slight.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Who's that? Mr. justice? how do you sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Why very well, and busy, where's your son.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: He's within sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Hum, and how does the young woman my cousin that came down with him.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: She's above, as a woman in her case may be.

sp.speaker: Justice.
sp.p: You have confessed it? then sirrah call in the officers; she's no cousin of mine; a mere trick to discover all.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: To discover? what?

sp.speaker: Justice.
sp.p: You shall know that anon: I think you have over reached you; o welcome, enter the house, and by virtue of my warrant which you have there, seize upon the bodily persons of those whose names are there written, to wit, one Mercury, and the wife of one Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: For what.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Away I say,
This gentleman shall certify you for what. Exit officer.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: He can accuse my son of nothing, he came from travel but within these two days?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: There hangs a tale.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: I should be sorry this should fall out at any time: but especially now sir; will you favour me so much, as to let me know of what you accuse him?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Upon suspicion of murder.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Murder? I defy thee.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.p: I pray God he may prove himself innocent.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Fie, say not so, you show yourself to be no good commonwealth's man: for the more are hanged, the better 'tis for the commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: By this rule you were best hang yourself.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I forgive your honest mirth ever: oh, welcome, welcome mark.
sp.stage: Enter mark and officers, with Mercury and the wife.
sp.l: Your pen, ink, and paper to take their examinations.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why do you pull me so? I'll go alone.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Let them stand, let them stand quietly, whilst they are examined?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What will you examine us of?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Of Antonio's murder.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why, he was my friend.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He was my husband.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: The more shame for you both; mark, your pen and ink.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Pray God all be well, I never knew any of these travellers come to good; I beseech you, sir, be favourable to my son.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Gentlewoman hold you content, I would it were come to that?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: For god's sake mother why kneel you to such a pig bribe fellow? he has surfeited of geese, and they have put him into a fit of justice, let him do his worst.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Is your paper ready?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: I am ready sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Accuse them sir, I command thee to lay down accusations against these persons in behalf of the state, and first look upon the parties to be accused, and deliver your name.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: My name is Curio, my murthered kinsman
If he were living now, I should not know him,
'Tis so long since we saw one another.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My cousin Curio?

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.p: But thus much from the mouths of his servants, and others, whose examinations I have in writing about me, I can accuse them of; this Mercury, the last night, but this last, lay in Antonio's house, and in the night he rose, raising Antonio, where privately they were in talk an hour, to what end I know not: but of likelihood, finding Antonio's house not a fit place to murder him in, he suffered him to go to bed again, but in the morning early, he trained him I think forth, after which time he never saw his home; his clothes were found near the place where Mercury was, and the people at first denied they saw him: but at last he made a frivolous tale, that there he shifted himself into a footman's habit: but in short, the next hour this woman went to Mercury, and in her coach they posted hither; true accusations, I have no more, and I will make none.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: No more? we need no more, sirrah, be drawing heir mittimus before we hear their answer. What say you sir? are you guilty of this murder?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Whether you are or no, confess, it will be the better for you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If I were guilty, your rhetoric could not fetch it forth: but though I am innocent, I confess, that if I were a stander by, these circumstances urged, which are true, would make me doubtless believe the accused parties to be guilty.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Write down, that he being a slander by, for so you see he is, doth doubtlessly believe the accused parties, which is himself, to be guilty.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I say no such thing.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Write it down I say, we'll try that.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I care not what you write, pray God you did not kill him for my love, though I am free from this, we both deserve.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Govern your tongue I pray you, all is well, my husband lives, I know it, and I see him.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: They whisper, sever them quickly I say officers why do you let them prompt one another, gentlewoman, what say you to this, are not you guilty?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No as I hope for mercy.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: But are not those circumstances true, that this gentleman hath so shortly and methodically delivered?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: They are; and what you do with me I care not,
Since he is dead, in whom was all my care:
You knew him not.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: No an't been better for you too, and you had never knewed him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why then you did not know the world's chief joy
His face so manly, as it had been made,
To fright the world, yet he so sweetly tempered;
That he would make himself a natural fool,
To do a noble kindness for a friend,
He was a man whose name I'll not out live,
Longer than heaven whose will must be obeyed;
Will have me do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I will quit thy kindness.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Before me she has made the tears stand in mine eyes, but I must be austere gentlewoman, you must confess this murder.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I cannot sir, I did it not, but I de sire to see those examinations which this gentleman acknowledges to have about him, for but late last night I received letters from the city, yet I heard of no confession, then.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: You shall see them time enough I warrant you, but letters you say you had, where are those letters?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir they are gone.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Gone? whither are they gone?
How have you disposed of 'em?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why sir they are for women's matters, and so I use 'em.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Who writ 'em?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A man of mine.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Who brought 'em?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A post.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: A post? there was some great haste sure, a ha where is that post?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir there he stands.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Does he so? bring hither that post, I am afraid that post will prove a knave; come hither post, what? what can you say concerning the murder of Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What's that to you?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: O post, you have no answer ready have you? I'll have one from you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You shall have no more from me than you have, you examine an honest gentleman and gentlewoman here, 'tis pity such fools as you should be i'the commission.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Say you so post, take away that post, whip him and bring him again quickly, I'll hamper you post.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Tis Antonio, I know him now as well, what an irregular fool is this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Whip me? hold off.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O good sir whip him, by his murmuring he should know some thing of my husband's death; that may quit me, for god's sake fetch't out.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Whip him I say.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who 'Is't dares whip me now?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O my loved husband.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: My most worthy friend? where have you been so long?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I cannot speak for joy.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Why, what's the matter now, and shall not law then have her course?

sp.speaker: Andra.
sp.p: It shall have no other course than it has I think

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: It shall have other course before I go, or I'll beat my brains, and I say it was not honestly done of him to discover himself before the parties accused were executed that law might have had her course, for then the kingdom flourishes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But such a wife as thou, had never any man, and such a friend as he, believe me wife, shall never be a good wife, love my friend, friend love my wife, hark friend.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Mark. if we can have nothing to do, you shall swear the peace of somebody .

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: By my troth I am sorry my wife is so obstinate, sooth if I could yet do thee any good, I wood, faith I wood.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I thank you sir, I have lost that passion.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Cousin Curio, you and I must be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It is my wish sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I should not have known you neither, 'tis so long
since we saw, we were but children then: but you have showed yourself an honest man to me.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I would be ever so.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Look you, who's there.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Say nothing to me, for thy peace is made.

sp.speaker: Kic.
sp.l: Sir, I can nothing say,
But that you are her father, you can both
Not only pardon, when you have a wrong,
But love where you have most injury.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I think I shall hear of no hanging this year, there a tinker and a whore yet, the crier said that robbed her, and are in prison, I hope they shall be hanged.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: No truly sir, they have broke prison.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: 'Tis no matter, than the jailor shall be hanged.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: You are deceived in that to sir, 'twas known to be against his will, and he hath got his pardon, I think for nothing, but if it doth cost him any thing, 'I'll pay it.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Mark up with your papers, away.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O you shall stay dinner, I have a couple of brawling neighbours, that I'll assure you will not agree, and you shall have the hearing of their matter.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Go, gentlemen, go in.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: O Viola, that no succeeding age,
Might lose the memory of what thou wert,
But such an overswayed sex is yours,
That all the virtuous actions you can do,
Are but as men will call them, and I swear,
'Tis my belief that women want but ways;
To praise their deeds, but men want deeds to praise.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: This comedy long forgotten, by some thought dead,
By us preserved, once more doth raise her head.
And to your noble censures does present,
Her outward form, and inward ornament.
Nor let this smell of arrogance, since 'tis known,
The makers that confessed it for their own
Were this way skilful, and without the crime
Of flatteries I may say did please the time;
The work itself too, when it first came forth,
In the opinion of men of worth,
Was well received, and favoured, though some rude
And harsh among the ignorant multitude,
(That relish gross food better than a dish,
That's cooked with care, and served into the wish,
Of curious palates) wanting wit and strength,
Truly to judge, condemned it for the length,
That fault's reformed, and now 'tis to be tried,
Before such judges 'twill not be denied
A free and noble hearing, nor fear I,
But 'twill deserve to have free liberty,
And give you cause (And with content) to say,
Their care was good that did revive this play.

div.head: The epilogue.
div.l: 'Tis ended; but my hopes, and fears begin,
Nor can it be imputed as a sin
In me to wish it favour, if this night,
To the judicious it hath given delight,
I have my ends, and may such for their grace,
Vouchsafed to this, find theirs in every place.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
